review.title: A Deep Learning Approach for Population Estimation from Satellite Imagery
review.abstract: Knowing where people live is a fundamental component of many decision making processes such as urban development, infectious disease containment, evacuation planning, risk management, conservation planning, and more. While bottom-up, survey driven censuses can provide a comprehensive view into the population landscape of a country, they are expensive to realize, are infrequently performed, and only provide population counts over broad areas. Population disaggregation techniques and population projection methods individually address these shortcomings, but also have shortcomings of their own. To jointly answer the questions of "where do people live" and "how many people live there," we propose a deep learning model for creating high-resolution population estimations from satellite imagery. Specifically, we train convolutional neural networks to predict population in the USA at a $0.01^{\circ} \times 0.01^{\circ}$ resolution grid from 1-year composite Landsat imagery. We validate these models in two ways: quantitatively, by comparing our model's grid cell estimates aggregated at a county-level to several US Census county-level population projections, and qualitatively, by directly interpreting the model's predictions in terms of the satellite image inputs. We find that aggregating our model's estimates gives comparable results to the Census county-level population projections and that the predictions made by our model can be directly interpreted, which give it advantages over traditional population disaggregation methods. In general, our model is an example of how machine learning techniques can be an effective tool for extracting information from inherently unstructured, remotely sensed data to provide effective solutions to social problems.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: Many countries introduce censors to gather rich information about the size of their populations, composition and demographics. While these censors only take place every 5 to 10 years depending on the country, they are very important for government policymakers and planners who estimate future demand for food, water, energy and services. In the United States, sub-national population estimates are widely used.

sections.heading: 2 Related Work
sections.text: This year, it has come to the point that there will only be one such process, and that is the question of the extent to which such a process has taken place.

sections.heading: 3 Methods
sections.text: The goal of this research is to make high-resolution population estimates from satellite imagery. To do this, we train CNNs that use satellite imagery of a particular area as input and output a population estimate for that area. We train our models on the American continent using U.S. Census and Landsat 7 1-year composite imagery from 2000. We test our models using the 2010 versions of the same datasets and evaluate population estimates in two ways: (1) aggregate the estimates of our model at the county level, and then compare them with projected county population numbers; and (2) show why our model makes predictions with respect to input image characteristics. sections.heading: 3.2 Model Architecture
sections.text: We experimented with various CNN architectures and hyperparameters using training and validation sets sampled from the 2000 datasets over an area in the southeastern United States. Our assumption is that a model architecture / hyperparameter set that can function well on this subset of the entire U.S. will perform equally well throughout the study area. Sampling of the training and validation sets was performed using the methodology described in Section 3.3. We took into account the 5 known "VGG" model architectures, VGG-A to VGG-E starting from (3) and variations on each of the 5 VGG architectures, which included exposure and batch normalization layers. We adapt the VGG architectures to use our input images of the size (74.74.7). Since we have divided our targets into 17 different classes, we reduce the output layer to 17 and use a soft max activation function.

sections.heading: 4 Results and Discussion
sections.text: Our results focus on validating the modeling methodology and are divided into three sections: assessing how good the population estimates of our model are when summarized at the district level in Section 4.1; interpreting why our models make the predictions they make in Section 4.2; and evaluating and explaining the per-pixel errors of our model versus the basic truth in Section 4.3.

sections.heading: 4.1 County level Estimates
sections.text: The four methods are as described in Section 3.3: POSTCENSAL, ACS5YR, CONVRAW and CONVAUG. None of these methods contains information about the true population figures for the target year, 2010, so the population must be derived either from detailed historical population and demographic data in the case of POSTCENSAL, supplementary survey information in the case of ACS5YEAR, or a combination of satellite and historical population data in the case of our methods CONVRAW and CONVAUG. We compare the predicted populations for all counties with any method taken from the base population and capture the mean absolute error (Mean AE), the mean absolute error (Median AE) and the mean absolute percentage error (MAPE). The results for this comparison can be found in Table 1, and the per county errors are illustrated in figure.

sections.heading: 4.2 Prediction Interpretability
sections.text: Because we cover some population breakdown methods in Section 2, we rely on ad hoc rules to assign the population of an administrative area to the grid cells that cover the same area. In some applications, the methods for determining these rules or the rules themselves are available, while in other products, such as Landsat (30; 31), the methodology is not public, and therefore subsequent years of predictions are not comparable. Furthermore, while some basic dasymetric heuristics, such as "people do not live on land where the slope is over 45," can be applied globally, more detailed heuristics may be region-specific. Our methodology circumvents these potential problems by generating the probability that a section of satellite imagery belongs to each population group, allowing us to show how confident our models are about a particular classification decision.

sections.heading: 4.3 Prediction Errors
sections.text: In Figure 6, we show three of these cases: Oak Ridge National Laboratory inOak Ridge, TN, Anniston Army Depot in Anniston, AL, and Walt Disney World in Orlando, FL. These locations all share the property of having many man-made structures and signals of human activity, without the "ground truth" characterizing a population from the census data. Walt Disney World has many structures similar to those in high-population neighborhoods, and will therefore always be misclassified by a model based solely on satellite imagery as input. In these cases, a traditional, asymmetric modeling approach to population dispersion will have an advantage over our model, since such an expanded approach could easily include layers describing large layers containing the army images that do not constitute useful observations with other content.
